title: 110_hr244
content: The Act may be cited as the "Technology Retraining and Investment Now Act for the 21st Century". The Congress finds that the value added by workers in the US and other countries is increasingly dependent on educational and training investments. There is a disparity in investment between the US and its trading partners, leading to declining educational performance in the US. This makes it challenging for US businesses to fund worker education compared to other countries. The global workforce environment creates competitive pressures on domestic companies to utilize highly educated knowledge workers in other countries. It is in the interest of the United States government to reverse this trend while maintaining trade obligations. Public-private partnerships, like the research and development tax credit, help advance the needs of citizens, businesses, and communities. Businesses are best suited to train the workforce for available jobs and develop new training methods. The United States aims to train its workforce for high-paying information and communications technology jobs to support retiring baby boomers. The Act encourages businesses to invest in education and training for knowledge workers in fields like technology, engineering, and manufacturing. The United States aims to train its workforce for high-paying information and communications technology jobs by encouraging employers to invest in education and training for knowledge workers. This will better utilize available training dollars and maximize the ability of newly trained individuals to utilize their acquired skills. SEC. 30D. Information and Communications Technology Education and Training Program Expenses. This section encourages employers to invest in education and training for knowledge workers to prepare them for high-paying ICT jobs. The tax code allows a credit of 50% for information and communications technology education and training expenses incurred by the taxpayer for employees or individuals. The maximum amount of expenses per individual is $4,000 for the taxable year. The tax code allows a credit of 50% for certain education and training expenses, with a maximum amount of $4,000 per individual. This amount increases to $5,000 for expenses related to programs in designated empowerment zones, schools with a high percentage of students eligible for free or reduced-cost lunches, or disaster areas designated by the Secretary of Agriculture or the President. The tax code offers a 50% credit for education and training expenses, up to $4,000 per individual, or $5,000 in specific zones or disaster areas designated by the Secretary of Agriculture or the President. This includes rural enterprise communities, Rural Economic Area Partnership Zones, areas under Indian tribal jurisdiction, or employers with 200 or fewer employees. The tax code provides a 50% credit for information technology education and training program expenses, including course work, certification testing, and other essential expenses. The term 'information technology education and training program' refers to training in IT workplace disciplines provided by accredited institutions or organizations in the US. Commercial IT training providers are private sector organizations offering such programs, while employer-owned IT training organizations provide training to employees using internal resources. Training programs must use industry-recognized disciplines and evaluation methods, comparable to institutional and commercial providers. No double benefit is allowed, and the credit for IT education expenses may be reduced by other credits. Certain rules apply, and the credit allowed should not exceed the regular tax reduced by other credits. The text discusses the allowable credits under subpart A and previous sections, in relation to the tentative minimum tax for the taxable year. Additionally, a clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for subpart B of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Sec. 30D outlines information and communications technology education and training program expenses. The effective date for the amendments is for taxable years starting after December 31, 2006. SEC. 4 defines eligible educational institutions. SEC. 4 amends the definition of eligible educational institution to include institutions under the Higher Education Act of 1965 and commercial information and communications technology training providers. The amendments apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2006. The Information Technology Training Certification Advisory Board is established with up to seven members appointed by the Secretary of the Treasury. The Board develops guidelines for computer science and information technology courses and certifications for approval by the Secretary. Meetings are held at least annually, and a Chairperson is elected from among the members who are not federal government employees. The Information Technology Training Certification Advisory Board, established with up to seven members appointed by the Secretary of the Treasury, submits an annual list of guidelines for computer science and information technology courses to the Secretary for approval. Board members serve without compensation but are allowed travel expenses. The Board is not subject to termination under the Federal Advisory Committee Act.
